details.title: A Two-Stage Failure Model for Bayesian Change Point Analysis

p: Jing Lin was awarded a B.A. degree in Management from Nanjing University of Science & Technology, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China in 2003; and a Ph.D. degree in Management from Nanjing University of Science & Technology, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China in 2008. Dr. Lin is currently a reliability engineer at SKF China Ltd. She has performed and directed research on the development and application of techniques such as Bayesian analysis, survival analysis, and MCMC methods for the analysis of reliability evaluation.

details.abstract: This paper presents a new approach for detecting certain change-points, which may disturb the evaluation of reliability models with covariates, via a two-stage failure model, and stochastic time-lagged regression functions. The proposed model is developed with the Bayesian survival analysis method, and thus the problems for censored (or truncated) data in reliability tests can be resolved. In addition, a Markov chain Monte Carlo method based on Gibbs sampling is used to dynamically simulate the Markov chain of the parameterspsila posterior distribution. Finally, a numeric example is discussed to demonstrate the proposed model.

references.title:
A change-point analysis for modeling incomplete
burn-in for light displays

context.text: Recently, [1] showed that reliability estimation could be improved substantially by using the change-points model to account for product burn-in effects.

references.text: S. J. Bae, P. H. Kvam, "A change-point analysis for modeling incomplete burn-in for light displays", IIE Trans., vol. 38, no. 6, pp. 489-498, 2006.

references.title:
Useful periods for lifetime distributions
with bathtub shaped hazard rate functions

context.text: Reference [2] proposed computationally tractable formal mathematical definitions for the lifetime distributions to identify the change-points with bathtub-shape hazard rate functions.

links.abstract: We propose computationally tractable formal mathematical definitions for the 'useful period' of lifetime distributions with bathtub shaped hazard rate functions. Detailed analysis of the reduced additive Weibull hazard rate function illustrates its utility for identifying such useful periods. Examples of several other bathtub shaped hazard rate functions are also presented with applications to lifetime data. The suggestion is made of defining and considering analogous 'stable periods' in the cas...

references.text: M. Bebbington, C. D. Lai, R. Zitikis, "Useful periods for lifetime distributions with bathtub shaped hazard rate functions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, no. 2, pp. 245-251, 2006.

references.title:
On changing points of mean residual life and failure rate
function for some generalized Weibull distributions

context.text: Furthermore, [3] discussed change-points of mean residual life, and hazard functions for certain generic Weibull distributions with focuses on their underlying associations.

references.text: M. Xie, T. N. Goh, Y. Tang, "On changing points of mean residual life and failure rate function for some generalized Weibull distributions", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 84, pp. 293-299, 2004.

references.title:
Testing the existence of change-point in NHPP software reliability
models

context.text: Reference [4] described new test statistics to test the existence of change-points in software reliability models.

references.text: J. Zhao, J. D. Wang, "Testing the existence of change-point in NHPP software reliability models", Communications in Statistics-Simulation and Computation, vol. 36, no. 3, pp. 607-619, 2007.

references.title:
The use of cumulative sums for detection
of change points in the rate parameter of a Poisson Process

context.text: Reference [5] proposed the use of cumulative sums for detections of change-points of a Poisson process when the failure rate is piecewise constant.

references.text: P. Galeano, "The use of cumulative sums for detection of change points in the rate parameter of a Poisson Process", Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, vol. 51, no. 12, pp. 6151-6165, 2007.

references.title:
A new Bayes estimate of the change point
in the hazard function

context.text: Reference [6] proposed an efficient estimate for the change point in the hazard function based on a Bayesian estimator via concerning the parameters of a recently proposed hazard function.

references.text: D. S. Karasoy, C. Kadilar, "A new Bayes estimate of the change point in the hazard function", Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, vol. 51, no. 6, pp. 2993-3001, 2007.

references.title:
Estimating the change point of a Poisson
rate parameter with a linear trend disturbance

context.text: Another approach based on the Maximum Likelihood Estimate method was given in [7].

references.text: M. B. Perry, J. J. Pignatiello, J. R. Simpson, "Estimating the change point of a Poisson rate parameter with a linear trend disturbance", Quality and Reliability Engineering International, vol. 22, no. 4, pp. 371-384, 2006.

references.title:
Application and reliability of change-point analyses for
detecting a defective stage in integrated circuit manufacturing

context.text: On the other hand, [8] presented change detection methods to pin-point the defective stage within a manufacturing process when the existence of a failure was only known at the end of the process relying on the MCMC method.

references.text: P. Besse, C. L. Gall, "Application and reliability of change-point analyses for detecting a defective stage in integrated circuit manufacturing", Communications in Statistics-Simulation and Computation, vol. 35, no. 2, pp. 479-496, 2006.

references.title: Parametric Statistical Change-Point Analysis

context.text: Reference [9] also presented a similar approach.

references.text: J. Chen, A. K. Gupta, Parametric Statistical Change-Point Analysis, 2000.

references.title:
Weighted log rank type statistics for comparing
survival curves when there is a lime lag in the effectiveness of a treatment

context.text: To identify & evaluate “supplements” which may prevent a specific cancer, [10] proposed the lagged regression model (also called the Z-L model) for cancer prevention.

The basic assumption of the model is that, before the trials, some unobservable latent quantities have already existed; and “we should then not expect the treatment to have any effect if the cancer is caused by tumors already existing at study entry” [10].

references.text: D. M. Zucker, E. Lakatos, "Weighted log rank type statistics for comparing survival curves when there is a lime lag in the effectiveness of a treatment", Biometrika, vol. 77, no. 4, pp. 853-864, 1990.

references.title: Likelihood ratio test for a change-point with survival data

context.text: Subsequently, [11] improved the Z-L model via a stochastic model, which takes the influences of treatments into consideration.

references.text: X. Luo, B. W. Turnbull, L. C. Clark, "Likelihood ratio test for a change-point with survival data", Biometrika, vol. 84, no. 3, pp. 555-565, 1997.

references.title: Models for survival data from cancer prevention studies

context.text: Accordingly, [12] established a new model by carrying out Bayesian inference, which motivated the research work described in this paper.

references.text: D. Sinha, J. G. Ibrahim, M. H. Chen, "Models for survival data from cancer prevention studies", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series B, vol. 64, no. 3, pp. 467-477, 2002.

references.title: Bayesian Reliability Analysis

context.text: Furthermore, for many kinds of environmental tests, the general hypothesis is that the failure mechanism is invariant [13].

references.text: H. F. Martz, R. A. Waller, Bayesian Reliability Analysis, 1982, John Wiley & Sons.
